Verification of the alleged tweet: The expert examined the alleged tweet by "@gayur_sheikh" that appealed to the Muslim community to sell poor quality food and beverages laced with chemicals to Hindus. They found that the Twitter handle no longer exists and discovered archived versions of tweets posted by this account, including the viral tweet. The presence of grammatical errors and inconsistencies in the tweet raised doubts about its authenticity.
Investigation into the source of the cla: The expert found that the claim was widely circulating on Facebook and was initially shared by a user named ऊधम सिंह चौधरी. They also noted that the same post was shared by the Facebook page 'हिन्दू राष्ट्र संघ' (Hindu Rashtra Sangh) in the past, accumulating over 800 shares. This information helped determine the origin and spread of the claim.
Confirmation from Darul Uloom Deoband: The expert contacted Ashraf Usmani, the media in-charge of Darul Uloom Deoband, to inquire about the viral claim. Usmani clarified that the claim was false and that they had not issued any such fatwa. This confirmation from an official representative of the institution helped establish the inauthenticity of the claim.
Examination of other tweets and account: The expert examined other archived tweets from the Twitter handle @gayur_sheikh, discovering that its earlier username was @sekh_gayor. They found a tweet where a user called the account "fake" and accused its owner of trying to incite a riot. This information provided additional context regarding the credibility of the account and its association with controversial content in the past.
